title: Think, Feel, Act!
description: This article explains the basics of cognitive-behavioral therapy and shows how thoughts, feelings, and behavior are interconnected. Through examples of a dialogue between a psychologist and a client, it illustrates how changing thinking patterns can improve emotional state and actions. At the end, you’ll find clear strategies that help break the vicious cycle of negative thoughts and feelings.

texts: Let’s look at the core principle of cognitive-behavioral therapy — the connection between thoughts, emotions, and our reactions.
Imagine a triangle whose corners are thoughts, feelings, and behavior.
These three elements don’t just coexist: they constantly interact, reinforcing or weakening one another.
Our thoughts are our inner dialogue, what we tell ourselves about what is happening.
They set our perspective — like glasses with particular lenses.
Emotions are our response to how we interpret events and what we think about them.
Joy, sadness, fear, anger — all of these are signals showing how we explain a situation to ourselves.
Our behavior is shaped by our thoughts and emotions.
It is how we act and respond to the world in specific circumstances.
And let’s not forget the body!
It is actively involved in the process and often reacts first.
Thoughts and emotions trigger physical reactions: rapid heartbeat, sweating, muscle tension when anxious; a smile and laughter — when joyful.
It often seems to us that emotions arise directly from events.
The car breaks down — we get angry.
We lose our wallet — we feel upset.
But CBT emphasizes that between the event and the emotion there is a mediator — our thoughts about what happened.
It is the interpretation of the event, not the event itself, that shapes how we feel.
To clearly see how this triad works, let’s look at an example: you are walking down the street and notice an ex-partner you once broke up with.
Thought: “He looks happy, and I’m a loser.”
Emotion: sadness, hurt, anger.
Physical reaction: tension in the shoulders, rapid heartbeat.
Behavior: you start crying, turn around and walk away to avoid meeting him.
Another example:
Situation: some acquaintances invite you to a party.
Thought: “I won’t be able to connect with anyone, and nobody will accept me.”
Emotion: anxiety, fear.
Physical reaction: heaviness in the stomach, sweaty palms, a lump in the throat.
Behavior: you decide not to go and stay at home.
You can see how a single thought triggers a whole chain of reactions.
This is also true for positive events.
Situation: you get a promotion at work.
Thought: “I did a great job, they value me as a professional.”
Emotion: joy, pride.
Behavior: you smile and call your friends to share the news.
Problems begin when we get stuck in a negative cycle.
One unhelpful thought triggers painful feelings and ineffective behavior, and they, in turn, reinforce that thought.
It’s like a snowball rolling down a hill and getting bigger and bigger.

test.question: Which of the following statements best describes the triad of thoughts, feelings, and behavior?
answers: Thoughts, feelings, and behavior function independently of each other, and changing one of them does not affect the others
Thoughts influence feelings and behavior, but feelings and behavior do not influence thoughts
Thoughts, feelings, and behavior are interconnected, and changing one of them can affect the other two
Only feelings influence thoughts and behavior, but not the other way around

texts: There is a way out — and CBT is exactly about this.
Let’s look at a dialogue between a client and a psychologist to see in more detail how this triad works:
dialog: I constantly feel anxious. It seems like I do everything wrong and that people around me are judging me.
Let’s break down a specific situation. What happened the last time you felt anxious?
I was giving a presentation at work. I was shaking, my voice was breaking. It felt like everyone was looking at me with disapproval.
What thought came up right before your anxiety spiked?
Most likely I thought: “I’m going to mess everything up” or “They’ll think I’m stupid.”
Good. So the thought is: “I’m going to mess everything up.” Emotions: anxiety, fear. Behavior: shaking, a trembling voice.
Now let’s check how accurate this thought is.
Was there real evidence that you ruined everything?
Well… The presentation wasn’t perfect, but it wasn’t a disaster either. My colleagues even asked questions.
So the thought “I’m going to mess everything up” was exaggerated. A more realistic version would be: “I’m nervous, but I can handle it.”
And even if I make a mistake during the presentation, that doesn’t mean I’m stupid. It means I’m human and I’m worried, and I don’t have much experience with public speaking yet.
If you had this kind of supportive thought, how would you feel and how would you behave?
I’d probably feel calmer and behave more confidently.

texts: By working with thoughts, we can change emotions and behavior for the better.
We will learn to notice negative thoughts, test how realistic they are, and replace them with more adaptive ones.
This helps break the vicious circle of negativity and helps you feel more stable.
This is how the basic model works; of course, individual nuances are added on top of it.
Someone with an eating disorder may fixate on their body and harshly criticize themselves for eating a pastry.
A person with anxiety can spend hours replaying unlikely catastrophic scenarios.
Don’t despair if you recognized yourself in these examples!
CBT is designed to help replace destructive thoughts and reactions with healthier, more flexible ones.
Next we will look in detail at how to interrupt vicious cycles and regain a sense of control.
It is important to remember: everyone has the ability to change their inner dialogue and respond to the world in a more constructive way.
